text.p: A 22-year-old convicted murderer was executed by lethal injection in Oklahoma on Thursday, the youngest person put to death since capital punishment resumed in the United States in 1976, officials said.
Scott Carpenter had pleaded no contest to first-degree murder in the February 1994 stabbing death of bait shop owner A.J. Kelley near Lake Eufaula, Oklahoma.
He waived his appeals and was executed shortly after midnight, officials said.
"He had no last words," prison spokeswoman Lee Mann said.

The execution was witnessed by four members of the victim's family, including his granddaughter and daughter-in-law, hours after state legislators amended a law to allow extended family of a victim to witness an execution.
Kelley, 56, was stabbed from behind in the neck at the Duchess Creek Bait and Grocery Store during an apparent robbery, prosecutors said.

Carpenter had pumped $37 worth of gas into a pick-up truck and took a sandwich, soda, cigarettes and chewing tobacco to the cash register. He then lured Kelley into the bait shop's minnow room and stabbed him. Kelly was found by two men, one a retired Oklahoma City detective, who walked in on the crime.
The men provided police with information, including a license plate number, used to capture Carpenter about an hour later, prosecutors said.

Even though Carpenter waived his appeals, death penalty opponents said prosecutors should have insisted on a review of the case by a higher court to ensure the death penalty was an appropriate sentence.

"It seems the best way to correct for mistakes would be to let the appeals process run," Richard Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Centre said. "I think the state has an interest to protect against mistakes."
The execution was the first this year and the ninth since capital punishment resumed in 1990 in Oklahoma, where 136 men and four women remained on death row, Mann said.
